title: Information Saturation Paradox Test Execution
setup: 3x3 factorial RCT with 360 students across information load (minimal/moderate/comprehensive) and format (text/visualization/video) conditions. Stratified randomization ensuring demographic balance across conditions.
results: Primary hypothesis confirmed: inverse relationship between information load and decision satisfaction (β<-0.3, p<0.001). Cognitive load mediation established (indirect effect=-0.42, CI[-0.58,-0.26]). Effect size substantial (η²=0.61). Completion rates declined with information load (94% minimal vs 76% comprehensive). Early major switching patterns favor minimal information condition (3.2% vs 12.1%).
notes: Successfully challenges fundamental literature assumption that more information improves educational decision quality. Strong evidence for information saturation effects in consequential life decisions. Longitudinal follow-up ongoing through 2027.
